paragraphs.title: What is the user’s data?
paragraphs.textCondensed: In this setting, the user does not need to register in order to use the app. Since we still need to identify our users in order to comply with the GDPR granted rights, we generate a random ID based on a device fingerprint and 256-AES encryption. Furthermore, we store the user’s image, the predicted probability of the disease and if the user decides to share the practitioner’s evaluation with us, we also retrieve the latter.

references.name: The Design of Rijndael: AES - The Advanced Encryption Standard

paragraphs.title: Encryption
paragraphs.textCondensed: The goal is to design an end-to-end system that guarantees safety during transfer and safety during storage of the user’s data. In order to achieve a high level of security, we will use the newest encryption standards. Encryption transforms data to text that is unreadable by anyone who does not have a decryption key and hence turns the personal data into pseudonymised data. So even if our company encounters a data breach during file transfer or storage, the data obtained by an attacker will be nonsense. So when the user uploads the image for analysis, we transfer the image and user’s ID using a secure socket layer (SSL) protocol which encrypts the data during transfer. To enforce maximum security, we will use server-side encryption to safe the user’s ID and image on our server and ensure encryption during storage. In this setting, the data can be sold. If the data is sold we decrypt the data and encrypt it with a new key that we share with the buyer. The data is then transferred to the other company.

paragraphs.title: Authentication and Authorization
paragraphs.textCondensed: To comply with the GDPR, we will control the data stored on our server. In this setting, the user authenticates using the encrypted ID generated when the user transfers an image. We use OAuth2 protected endpoints to restrict access to the IDs and images stored on our server. OAuth2 allows us to grant permission such that each user can request to update, retrieve or delete his/her image with a REST request. Hence users are only able to retrieve, update or delete their own taken images. If the data is sold while the user did not withdraw his/her consent yet, we are not responsible for the other company’s usage of his/her data.

paragraphs.title: Where is my data stored?
paragraphs.textCondensed: To further comply with the GDPR, our server is located in Switzerland and therefore the encrypted data is stored in Switzerland. If the data is sold, we are not responsible where the data of the other company is located.

paragraphs.title: Model
paragraphs.textCondensed: We use a deep learning model to get a prediction (probability of Tonsillitis) based on the user’s image. More specifically, we utilize a convolutional neural network (CNN) which are popular among image classification tasks. The animation shows how the CNN extracts relevant patterns and feeds them into a classical neural network. This network then calculates the probability of the user’s chance of having Tonsillitis. The emphasis when evaluating the model is to minimize the chance that a user has Tonsillitis but is not recognized by the model (recall measure). In this setting, the neural network is deployed on our server and therefore, we can use a CNN that requires more storage but is more powerful. Furthermore, the CNN can be updated regularly using the newest pictures we collected without any user action (no app update required).
